slide.text: Creating a Handler

slide.name: Content Placeholder 2

runs.text: Handlers are classes which implement the

paragraphs.text: Handlers are classes which implement the IAgent interface, with the MessageServiceMethod attributes decorating api methods.

runs.text: A handler serves to direct messages to a dialog and return a message.

paragraphs.text: A handler serves to direct messages to a dialog and return a message.

slide.text:
Handlers are classes which implement the IAgent interface, with the MessageServiceMethod attributes decorating api methods.

A handler serves to direct messages to a dialog and return a message.

slide.name: Title 1
slide.text: MessageServiceMethod

slide.name: Content Placeholder 2

runs.text: attributes define the handler’s API, by marking methods with a name that the
can use to execute your handlers methods.

paragraphs.text: MessageServiceMethod attributes define the handler’s API, by marking methods with a name that the MessageService can use to execute your handlers methods.

slide.text: MessageServiceMethod attributes define the handler’s API, by marking methods with a name that the MessageService can use to execute your handlers methods.

slide.name: Title 1
slide.text: Setup the Handler

slide.name: Content Placeholder 4

runs.text: handles communication to and from your agent.

paragraphs.text: MessageService handles communication to and from your agent.

runs.text: , executing the desired method, passing the parameters and replying back to the originator of the request.

paragraphs.text: Call the MessageService.Setup<T> with T being a class as described. MessageService handles creating instances of T, executing the desired method, passing the parameters and replying back to the originator of the request.

slide.text:
MessageService handles communication to and from your agent.

Call the MessageService.Setup<T> with T being a class as described. MessageService handles creating instances of T, executing the desired method, passing the parameters and replying back to the originator of the request.

slide.name: Title 1
slide.text: Define a Dialog

slide.name: Content Placeholder 2

runs.text: is the most convenient way of creating an agent dialog. The
class adds natural language capabilities to your agent which can be used to determine the intention of the user.

paragraphs.text: Using a LuisDialog is the most convenient way of creating an agent dialog. The LuisDialog class adds natural language capabilities to your agent which can be used to determine the intention of the user.

slide.text:
Using a LuisDialog is the most convenient way of creating an agent dialog. The LuisDialog class adds natural language capabilities to your agent which can be used to determine the intention of the user.

Find more information about LuisDialogs : http://docs.botframework.com/sdkreference/csharp/

slide.name: Title 1
slide.text: LUIS

slide.name: Content Placeholder 2

runs.text: LUIS(Language Understanding Intelligent Service) offers a fast and effective way of adding language understanding to applications.

With LUIS, you can use pre-existing, world-class, pre-built models from Bing and Cortana whenever they suit your purposes -- and when you need specialized models, LUIS guides you through the process of quickly building them.

paragraphs.text: LUIS(Language Understanding Intelligent Service) offers a fast and effective way of adding language understanding to applications. With LUIS, you can use pre-existing, world-class, pre-built models from Bing and Cortana whenever they suit your purposes -- and when you need specialized models, LUIS guides you through the process of quickly building them.

slide.text:
LUIS(Language Understanding Intelligent Service) offers a fast and effective way of adding language understanding to applications. With LUIS, you can use pre-existing, world-class, pre-built models from Bing and Cortana whenever they suit your purposes -- and when you need specialized models, LUIS guides you through the process of quickly building them.
https://www.luis.ai/Home/About

runs.text: These dialogs will automatically direct messages to the matching
decorated functions. For example, if the “

paragraphs.text: These dialogs will automatically direct messages to the matching LuisIntent decorated functions. For example, if the “INTENT_CreatePurchasOrder” is received, then the CreatePurchasOrder function is called.

slide.text: These dialogs will automatically direct messages to the matching LuisIntent decorated functions. For example, if the “INTENT_CreatePurchasOrder” is received, then the CreatePurchasOrder function is called.

slide.name: Title 1
slide.text: How do Dialogs work?

slide.name: Content Placeholder 2

runs.text: This is illustration shows a Timesheet Dialog which uses a Create Timesheet Dialog, which in turn uses a Boolean Dialog to process a message. In this example, the Timesheet Dialog has determined that the desire of the user is to “create a timesheet”. Assume that the agent had inquired to the user if they would like to view the current state of their timesheet. The user has replied “Yes”, so a
dialog processes the “Yes” reply and will return a true value in the callback.

paragraphs.text: This is illustration shows a Timesheet Dialog which uses a Create Timesheet Dialog, which in turn uses a Boolean Dialog to process a message. In this example, the Timesheet Dialog has determined that the desire of the user is to “create a timesheet”. Assume that the agent had inquired to the user if they would like to view the current state of their timesheet. The user has replied “Yes”, so a boolean dialog processes the “Yes” reply and will return a true value in the callback.

slide.text: This is illustration shows a Timesheet Dialog which uses a Create Timesheet Dialog, which in turn uses a Boolean Dialog to process a message. In this example, the Timesheet Dialog has determined that the desire of the user is to “create a timesheet”. Assume that the agent had inquired to the user if they would like to view the current state of their timesheet. The user has replied “Yes”, so a boolean dialog processes the “Yes” reply and will return a true value in the callback.

slide.name: Title 1

runs.text: When the user sends a message which matches the “Your Intent” the
will return a message to the user, “question for the user”. When an appropriate reply is received the “Callback” will be called with the result.

paragraphs.text: When the user sends a message which matches the “Your Intent” the IntentHandler will be called. Then the PromptDialog will return a message to the user, “question for the user”. When an appropriate reply is received the “Callback” will be called with the result.

slide.text: When the user sends a message which matches the “Your Intent” the IntentHandler will be called. Then the PromptDialog will return a message to the user, “question for the user”. When an appropriate reply is received the “Callback” will be called with the result.
